channel.title: Yahoo News - Latest News & Headlines
channel.description: The latest news and headlines from Yahoo! News. Get breaking news stories and in-depth coverage with videos and photos.

item.title: Robin Williams' death highlights Parkinson's-depression link
item.description: Yahoo's Katie Couric interviews mental health leader for context in wake of actor's death.
item.media:text: Yahoo's Katie Couric interviews mental health leader for context in wake of actor's death.

item.title: Texas' Perry indicted on two felonies for veto threat
item.description: Jury: Gov. Rick Perry threatened corruption prosecutors in major abuse of power.
item.media:text: Jury: Gov. Rick Perry threatened corruption prosecutors in major abuse of power.

item.title: Ex-cop who burned body again gets 17 years
item.description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) — For a second time, a former New Orleans police officer has been sentenced to more than 17 years in prison for burning the body of a man shot to death by another New Orleans police officer in the chaotic days following Hurricane Katrina.
item.media:text: NEW ORLEANS (AP) — For a second time, a former New Orleans police officer has been sentenced to more than 17 years in prison for burning the body of a man shot to death by another New Orleans police officer in the chaotic days following Hurricane Katrina.

item.title: Return to best will take time, Phelps says
item.description: American swimming superstar Michael Phelps said on Saturday it would take time to return to his best ahead of next week's Pan Pacific Championships in Australia. Phelps, the 18 Olympic gold medallist, returned to competition in April after a retirement that lasted nearly two years and finished this month's US Championships without a title. Phelps, 29, is preparing for his first international meet since the 2012 London Olympics after ending his retirement. The greatest Olympian of all time will contest the 200 metres individual medley and the 100 metres butterfly at the four-day PanPacs starting on Thursday as part of a 60-strong US team also featuring Ryan Lochte, Missy Franklin and Katie Ledecky.
item.media:text: American swimming superstar Michael Phelps said on Saturday it would take time to return to his best ahead of next week's Pan Pacific Championships in Australia. Phelps, the 18 Olympic gold medallist, returned to competition in April after a retirement that lasted nearly two years and finished this month's US Championships without a title. Phelps, 29, is preparing for his first international meet since the 2012 London Olympics after ending his retirement. The greatest Olympian of all time will contest the 200 metres individual medley and the 100 metres butterfly at the four-day PanPacs starting on Thursday as part of a 60-strong US team also featuring Ryan Lochte, Missy Franklin and Katie Ledecky.

item.title: Russian hacking suspect ordered held until trial
item.description: SEATTLE (AP) — A federal judge ordered the son of a prominent Russian lawmaker to remain in custody until his trial on computer hacking charges, after a prosecutor said evidence recovered from his laptop after his arrest in the Maldives gave new insight into the breadth of his activities.
item.media:text: SEATTLE (AP) — A federal judge ordered the son of a prominent Russian lawmaker to remain in custody until his trial on computer hacking charges, after a prosecutor said evidence recovered from his laptop after his arrest in the Maldives gave new insight into the breadth of his activities.

item.title: Nintendo responds to petition to include Robin Williams tribute in Zelda game
item.description: A fan-petition for Nintendo to include a character named after Robin Williams, who died earlier this week, has so far collected almost 90,000 signatures. Nintendo tonight responded to Polygon's request for comment on the Change.org petition, which asks that Nintendo name one of its non-player characters 'Robin' in the next Zelda game. Williams, who had recently been diagnosed with a serious illness and suffered from Depression, took his own life on Monday.
item.media:text: A fan-petition for Nintendo to include a character named after Robin Williams, who died earlier this week, has so far collected almost 90,000 signatures. Nintendo tonight responded to Polygon's request for comment on the Change.org petition, which asks that Nintendo name one of its non-player characters 'Robin' in the next Zelda game. Williams, who had recently been diagnosed with a serious illness and suffered from Depression, took his own life on Monday.

item.title: Who stopped China Catholics going to South Korea?
item.description: BEIJING (AP) — Days after Chinese officials blocked Catholics from seeing the pope in South Korea, it's still unclear who was behind the action or why it was taken.
item.media:text: BEIJING (AP) — Days after Chinese officials blocked Catholics from seeing the pope in South Korea, it's still unclear who was behind the action or why it was taken.

item.title: Perry indictment exposes Texas' political divide
item.description: AUSTIN, Texas (AP) — A grand jury has indicted Texas Republican Gov. Rick Perry on two felony counts of abuse of power for making good on a veto threat — a case the possible 2016 presidential hopeful is dismissing as nakedly political, but which his opponents say is just deserts.
item.media:text: AUSTIN, Texas (AP) — A grand jury has indicted Texas Republican Gov. Rick Perry on two felony counts of abuse of power for making good on a veto threat — a case the possible 2016 presidential hopeful is dismissing as nakedly political, but which his opponents say is just deserts.

item.title: Mexico acid leak leaves orange river, toxic water
item.description: Ramona Yesenia stood in her town square with two empty jugs, waiting for water to replace the municipal supply contaminated by a chemical spill that turned Mexico's Sonora river orange. Yesenia is one of 20,000 people left without water since a massive sulfuric acid leak last week at the Buenavista copper mine in northwestern Mexico, one of the largest in the world. An estimated 40,000 cubic meters (10.6 million gallons) of sulfuric acid, which is used to dissolve copper from ore for processing, leaked out of a holding tank at the mine, owned by leading Latin American mining company Grupo Mexico. Juan Rebolledo, Grupo Mexico's vice president for international relations, downplayed the impact.
item.media:text: Ramona Yesenia stood in her town square with two empty jugs, waiting for water to replace the municipal supply contaminated by a chemical spill that turned Mexico's Sonora river orange. Yesenia is one of 20,000 people left without water since a massive sulfuric acid leak last week at the Buenavista copper mine in northwestern Mexico, one of the largest in the world. An estimated 40,000 cubic meters (10.6 million gallons) of sulfuric acid, which is used to dissolve copper from ore for processing, leaked out of a holding tank at the mine, owned by leading Latin American mining company Grupo Mexico. Juan Rebolledo, Grupo Mexico's vice president for international relations, downplayed the impact.

item.title: Back on the US team; step 1 complete for Phelps
item.description: BRISBANE, Australia (AP) — Michael Phelps is acting like the new guy on the team, introducing himself to swimmers he doesn't know and trying to make some new friends.
item.media:text: BRISBANE, Australia (AP) — Michael Phelps is acting like the new guy on the team, introducing himself to swimmers he doesn't know and trying to make some new friends.

item.title: New FAA ruling effectively bans ridesharing for planes
item.description: A recent FAA ruling has left Uber of air travel-hopeful AirPooler and other startups like it in a legal bind. The agency yesterday stated that private pilots who don't hold a special government-issued certificate are banned from publicly offering seats on their planes for a fee. The ruling is meant to clarify a 1963 proposal that allows for pilots to privately ask passengers to split travel expenses like the cost of fuel.
item.media:text: A recent FAA ruling has left Uber of air travel-hopeful AirPooler and other startups like it in a legal bind. The agency yesterday stated that private pilots who don't hold a special government-issued certificate are banned from publicly offering seats on their planes for a fee. The ruling is meant to clarify a 1963 proposal that allows for pilots to privately ask passengers to split travel expenses like the cost of fuel.

item.title: Swimming - Return to best will take time - Phelps
item.description: - American swimming superstar Michael Phelps said Saturday it would take time to return to his best ahead of next week's Pan Pacific Championships in Australia. Phelps, 29, is preparing for his first international meet since the 2012 London Olympics after ending a two-year retirement from swimming. The greatest Olympian of all time will contest the 200 metres individual medley and the 100 metres butterfly at the four-day PanPacs starting on Thursday in Brisbane.
item.media:text: - American swimming superstar Michael Phelps said Saturday it would take time to return to his best ahead of next week's Pan Pacific Championships in Australia. Phelps, 29, is preparing for his first international meet since the 2012 London Olympics after ending a two-year retirement from swimming. The greatest Olympian of all time will contest the 200 metres individual medley and the 100 metres butterfly at the four-day PanPacs starting on Thursday in Brisbane.

item.title: Tens of thousands protest Pakistan's government
item.description: Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters gathered in Pakistan's capital Islamabad late Friday in the pouring rain following the arrival of convoys led by a cricket star-turned-politician and a fiery anti-Taliban cleric.
item.media:text: Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters gathered in Pakistan's capital Islamabad late Friday in the pouring rain following the arrival of convoys led by a cricket star-turned-politician and a fiery anti-Taliban cleric.

item.title: Iraq Yazidis fear for thousands kidnapped by jihadists
item.description: In a dusty, ill-equipped camp in northern Iraq, Yazidis fleeing a jihadist offensive say members of their families -- men, women and even babies -- have been abducted by militants. The mass kidnappings by the Islamic State (IS) jihadist group targeted those who either refused or simply could not flee a string of villages around Mount Sinjar, one of the minority's main ancestral homes in northern Iraq. The refugees say the women and children are being held in IS-controlled prisons in Nineveh province, where a sweeping jihadist-led offensive was launched in June, and that many of the men are feared to have been executed. Other Yazidis, just as distraught, gave similar accounts.
item.media:text: In a dusty, ill-equipped camp in northern Iraq, Yazidis fleeing a jihadist offensive say members of their families -- men, women and even babies -- have been abducted by militants. The mass kidnappings by the Islamic State (IS) jihadist group targeted those who either refused or simply could not flee a string of villages around Mount Sinjar, one of the minority's main ancestral homes in northern Iraq. The refugees say the women and children are being held in IS-controlled prisons in Nineveh province, where a sweeping jihadist-led offensive was launched in June, and that many of the men are feared to have been executed. Other Yazidis, just as distraught, gave similar accounts.

item.title: Storm-hit Hawaii voters decide US Senate primary
item.description: PAHOA, Hawaii (AP) — A steady flow of residents recovering from Tropical Storm Iselle cast votes Friday to finally decide who wins Hawaii's Democratic U.S. Senate primary, a race expected to determine who will serve the final two years of the late U.S. Sen. Daniel Inouye's term in the strongly Democratic state.
item.media:text: PAHOA, Hawaii (AP) — A steady flow of residents recovering from Tropical Storm Iselle cast votes Friday to finally decide who wins Hawaii's Democratic U.S. Senate primary, a race expected to determine who will serve the final two years of the late U.S. Sen. Daniel Inouye's term in the strongly Democratic state.

item.title: Sharapova rallies to beat spirited Halep
item.description: Maria Sharapova won a re-match of her French Open title victory over Simona Halep, rallying for a 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 win to reach the semi-finals of the Cincinnati Masters. The reigning Roland Garros holder will play Ana Ivanovic after the Serb ninth seed defeated Ukrainian teenager Elina Svitolina 6-2, 6-3 in less than an hour on Friday night. Sharapova had to make a great escape against world number two Halep, who has burst into WTA prominence over the past year. Sharapova won her fifth match against Halep without a loss.
item.media:text: Maria Sharapova won a re-match of her French Open title victory over Simona Halep, rallying for a 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 win to reach the semi-finals of the Cincinnati Masters. Sharapova had to make a great escape against world number two Halep, who has burst into WTA prominence over the past year. Sharapova won her fifth match against Halep without a loss.

item.title: Huge crowds greet pope at martyr beatification
item.description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — Pope Francis beatified 124 Korean martyrs on Saturday, telling hundreds of thousands of people who turned out for his open-air Mass that their ancestors' willingness to die rather than renounce their faith two centuries ago was a model for Asian missionaries today.
item.media:text: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — Pope Francis beatified 124 Korean martyrs on Saturday, telling hundreds of thousands of people who turned out for his open-air Mass that their ancestors' willingness to die rather than renounce their faith two centuries ago was a model for Asian missionaries today.

item.title: Bobblehead bobble: Cabrera MVPs show wrong league
item.description: DETROIT (AP) — There was a bobblehead bobble at Comerica Park when it came to Miguel Cabrera.
item.media:text: DETROIT (AP) — There was a bobblehead bobble at Comerica Park when it came to Miguel Cabrera.

item.title: S. Koreans express pride, surprise at pope visit
item.description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — They came from across South Korea to see Pope Francis or, if the crowds were too big to get close enough, to hear his voice emanate from speakers set up around a stage during a Mass to beatify 124 martyrs.
item.media:text: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — They came from across South Korea to see Pope Francis or, if the crowds were too big to get close enough, to hear his voice emanate from speakers set up around a stage during a Mass to beatify 124 martyrs.

item.title: Man shot in the back in North Philadelphia
item.description: Authorities say a man was shot multiple times in the back in North Philadelphia.
item.media:text: Authorities say a man was shot multiple times in the back in North Philadelphia.

item.title: NASCAR bars drivers from exiting cars after wrecks
item.description: BROOKLYN, Mich. (AP) — Even Jimmie Johnson has a temper — one that was on display long before he became a six-time champion and one of NASCAR's most respected drivers.
item.media:text: BROOKLYN, Mich. (AP) — Even Jimmie Johnson has a temper — one that was on display long before he became a six-time champion and one of NASCAR's most respected drivers.

item.title: US warns 'provocative' Russia as Ukraine tensions rise
item.description: Washington urged Moscow to stop its "extremely dangerous and provocative" activities after Ukraine said it had destroyed part of a Russian military convoy that entered its territory. US National Security Council spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden warned that "the escalation in Russian activity designed to destabilise Ukraine in recent weeks is extremely dangerous and provocative". NATO accused Russia of active involvement in the "destabilisation" of eastern Ukraine, where pro-Kremlin separatists have been fighting against Kiev for four months. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko told British Prime Minister David Cameron that government artillery had destroyed a "considerable part" of a small military convoy that entered the country, the presidency said in a statement.
item.media:text: Washington urged Moscow to stop its "extremely dangerous and provocative" activities after Ukraine said it had destroyed part of a Russian military convoy that entered its territory. US National Security Council spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden warned that "the escalation in Russian activity designed to destabilise Ukraine in recent weeks is extremely dangerous and provocative". NATO accused Russia of active involvement in the "destabilisation" of eastern Ukraine, where pro-Kremlin separatists have been fighting against Kiev for four months. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko told British Prime Minister David Cameron that government artillery had destroyed a "considerable part" of a small military convoy that entered the country, the presidency said in a statement.

item.title: UN moves against Iraq Islamists amid reports of massacre
item.description: The UN Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution aimed at weakening Islamists in Iraq amid reports of Islamic State jihadists killing dozens of residents in besieged ethnic Yazidi areas. US President Barack Obama said a first week of air strikes had broken the siege of the northern Sinjar mountain where civilians had been hiding from jihadists for more than 10 days. The US carried out more air strikes on Friday, the military said, after receiving reports that Islamic State "terrorists were attacking civilians" in the area. As aid groups tried to cope with the hundreds of thousands of people displaced by Islamist advances in northern Iraq, ingredients of a fight-back began falling into place.
item.media:text: The UN Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution aimed at weakening Islamists in Iraq amid reports of Islamic State jihadists killing dozens of residents in besieged ethnic Yazidi areas. US President Barack Obama said a first week of air strikes had broken the siege of the northern Sinjar mountain where civilians had been hiding from jihadists for more than 10 days. The US carried out more air strikes on Friday, the military said, after receiving reports that Islamic State "terrorists were attacking civilians" in the area. As aid groups tried to cope with the hundreds of thousands of people displaced by Islamist advances in northern Iraq, ingredients of a fight-back began falling into place.

item.title: Brady leads Patriots to 42-35 win over Eagles
item.description: The New England Patriots capitalized on four turnovers to beat the Philadelphia Eagles 42-35 on Friday night.
item.media:text: The New England Patriots capitalized on four turnovers to beat the Philadelphia Eagles 42-35 on Friday night.

item.title: Revel casino to close 8 days earlier than planned
item.description: Revel Casino Hotel, the $2.4 billion resort that opened just over two years ago as a hoped-for savior for Atlantic City's sinking revenues, is closing a week earlier than planned.
item.media:text: Revel Casino Hotel, the $2.4 billion resort that opened just over two years ago as a hoped-for savior for Atlantic City's sinking revenues, is closing a week earlier than planned.

item.title: Ferguson cops identify officer, allege Michael Brown robbed store
item.description: Police on Friday identified the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager and released documents alleging the young man had been a suspect in a robbery.
item.media:text: Police on Friday identified the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager and released documents alleging the young man had been a suspect in a robbery.

item.title: Wake held for victims, cause 'undetermined' in fatal SW Phila fire
item.description: Just hours after the Philadelphia Fire Department said they could not determine the cause of the fire that killed four children back in July, a wake was held for the victims.
item.media:text: Just hours after the Philadelphia Fire Department said they could not determine the cause of the fire that killed four children back in July, a wake was held for the victims.

item.title: Taney Dragons win 4-0 in debut game of Little League World Series
item.description: Philadelphia's Taney Dragons beat Tennessee 4-0 on Friday in their first game of the Little League World Series.
item.media:text: Philadelphia's Taney Dragons beat Tennessee 4-0 on Friday in their first game of the Little League World Series.

item.title: None brazen enough to bid on possibly booby-trapped land
item.description: No one bid for the compound of a tax-evading couple convicted of amassing an arsenal of weapons and holding federal law enforcement officials at bay for months.
item.media:text: No one bid for the compound of a tax-evading couple convicted of amassing an arsenal of weapons and holding federal law enforcement officials at bay for months.

item.title: Boko Haram kidnaps 100
item.description: Most captives were freed by forces from Chad, officials said.
item.media:text: Most captives were freed by forces from Chad, officials said.

item.title: 11 dead in Quetta airbase attacks
item.description: Eleven Taliban-linked militants were killed and 13 members of the Pakistani security forces wounded in attacks on two air force bases in the west Pakistan city of Quetta on Thursday, officials said. Pakistan's military has been fighting an offensive against the Taliban insurgency in the remote, largely lawless region of North Waziristan on the Afghanistan border since June. A wing of the Pakistani Taliban said they had carried out Thursday night's raids in response to that offensive. "It is a revenge for the army's killing of innocent people in North and South Waziristan," said Ghalib Mehsud, who said he was a commander and spokesman for the Fidayeen Islam, a Taliban wing responsible for training suicide bombers.
item.media:text: Eleven Taliban-linked militants were killed and 13 members of the Pakistani security forces wounded in attacks on two air force bases in the west Pakistan city of Quetta on Thursday, officials said. Pakistan's military has been fighting an offensive against the Taliban insurgency in the remote, largely lawless region of North Waziristan on the Afghanistan border since June. A wing of the Pakistani Taliban said they had carried out Thursday night's raids in response to that offensive. "It is a revenge for the army's killing of innocent people in North and South Waziristan," said Ghalib Mehsud, who said he was a commander and spokesman for the Fidayeen Islam, a Taliban wing responsible for training suicide bombers.

item.title: Chief: Cop didn't know Brown was suspect
item.description: FERGUSON, Mo. (AP) — Police on Friday identified the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager and released documents alleging the young man had been suspected of stealing a $48.99 box of cigars from a convenience store in a "strong-arm" robbery shortly before he was killed.
item.media:text: FERGUSON, Mo. (AP) — Police on Friday identified the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager and released documents alleging the young man had been suspected of stealing a $48.99 box of cigars from a convenience store in a "strong-arm" robbery shortly before he was killed.

item.title: SeaWorld to build bigger enclosures for killer whales in U.S.
item.description: Theme park operator SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. said on Friday it would nearly double the size of its San Diego killer whale tank and expand similar enclosures in Florida and Texas amid criticism over its treatment of the animals. "The new projects will build on SeaWorld’s legacy of providing state-of-the-art, innovative homes for its animals," the company said in a statement. Expansions will follow for the company's tanks in Orlando and San Antonio, Texas, SeaWorld said. The group said SeaWorld should instead put the captive orcas in seaside sanctuaries with the goal of releasing them into the ocean.
item.media:text: Theme park operator SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. said on Friday it would nearly double the size of its San Diego killer whale tank and expand similar enclosures in Florida and Texas amid criticism over its treatment of the animals. "The new projects will build on SeaWorld’s legacy of providing state-of-the-art, innovative homes for its animals," the company said in a statement. The group said SeaWorld should instead put the captive orcas in seaside sanctuaries with the goal of releasing them into the ocean.

item.title: ISIL may be planning attacks on U.S. soil
item.description: Exclusive: Well-armed group may have America in its cross-hairs.

item.title: Jet Airways flight plunges 5,000 ft. as pilot dozes off, co-pilot busy on iPad
item.description: A potential incident was averted when a Jet Airways flight from Mumbai to Brussels dropped 5,000 feet in airspace while the pilot was "on rest."

item.title: Cops: Amish girls kidnapped by more than 1 person
item.description: A New York sheriff says two young Amish sisters now safe at home were kidnapped from their family farm stand and police are seeking more than one person responsible.

item.title: Notre Dame players investigated for possible academic fraud
item.description: Notre Dame administrative officials are investigating instances of potential academic fraud on campus that could include several members of the Fighting Irish football team, sources have told Yahoo Sports.
item.media:text: Notre Dame administrative officials are investigating instances of potential academic fraud on campus that could include several members of the Fighting Irish football team, sources have told Yahoo Sports.

item.title: Report: CDC scientist kept quiet about flu virus blunder
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — A government scientist kept silent about a potentially dangerous lab blunder and revealed it only after workers in another lab noticed something fishy, according to an internal investigation.
item.media:text: NEW YORK (AP) — A government scientist kept silent about a potentially dangerous lab blunder and revealed it only after workers in another lab noticed something fishy, according to an internal investigation.

item.title: Gore sues Al Jazeera America for unpaid millions
item.description: Former Vice President Al Gore is suing Al Jazeera America, saying the news network is withholding tens of millions of dollars that it owes for buying Current TV from him and other shareholders for $500 ...
